misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for a physics problem instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for physical quantities (v0, v1, t) and reads three double values instead of reading five integers as required by the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that calculates average acceleration from an initial velocity, final velocity, and time, so I only need to read these three values as doubles.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly five integer values from the user (e.g., using nextInt()), because the task is to compute the sum of even numbers among those five integers.
symptoms: Prompt text mentions v0, v1, and t instead of five integers
Program only consumes three inputs from the user
Program uses nextDouble() instead of nextInt()
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a completely different textbook/example problem (average acceleration) instead of the specified task (sum of even numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design your input based on it: you need to ask the user for five integers and read them (e.g., with nextInt()) rather than reading three doubles for velocities and time.
related_concepts: Mapping problem description to input variables

evidence.note: Prompt and input logic are for three double values v0, v1, and t, not five integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any loop to process multiple inputs; instead, it reads a fixed small number of values directly. For the required task, a loop is needed to handle five integers in a scalable way.

symptoms: No for or while loop appears in main
Inputs are read only by three direct nextDouble() calls

misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a single formula-based calculation (average acceleration) that does not require iteration, instead of the specified problem which naturally calls for looping over a fixed number of inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for-loop that runs five times. Inside the loop, read one integer, check if it is even, and if so add it to a running sum.
related_concepts: Iteration over a fixed count of inputs

evidence.note: Entire main method shows sequential statements with no loop structure to iterate over five inputs.

misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to test for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (e.g., with n % 2 == 0). Instead, it directly applies a physics formula to three inputs without any branching.
misconceptions.student_belief: For this task, I just need to plug the three input values into a formula without making any decisions about them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each of the five integers read, the program should use a conditional statement (if) to test whether the number is even using n % 2 == 0, and only then add it to the sum.
symptoms: No if or conditional statements in the code
No use of the modulo (%) operator
All input values are treated identically in a simple arithmetic expression
misconceptions.root_cause: The student solved a different, formula-based problem (average acceleration) that requires no conditional logic, so they never introduced the even-number check required by this question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer inside a loop, write an if-statement like `if (n % 2 == 0) { sum += n; }` to ensure only even numbers contribute to the total.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditional constructs at all in the provided code, and the rubric explicitly requires an even-number check.

evidence.snippet: public class AccelerationCalculator { public static void main(String[] args) { Scanner input_reader = new Scanner(System.in); System.out.print("Enter v0, v1, and t: "); double v0 = input_reader.nextDouble(); double finalVelocity = input_reader.nextDouble(); double t_val = input_reader.nextDouble(); double avg_acceleration = (finalVelocity - v0) / t_val; System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + avg_acceleration); } }
evidence.note: The entire program solves an acceleration calculation problem, not the sum of even numbers problem. The class name, variable names (v0, finalVelocity, t_val), and the formula (acceleration = Δv/Δt) are from a completely different assignment.
